unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Probability of $5$ Heads
question_text:
A fair coin is tossed $8\text{ times}$.
What is the probability that $5$ of the resulting tosses land on heads?
solution:
It correctly uses the binomial formula:

P(x)=\dbinom{n}{x}{ \pi }^{ x }{ (1-\pi ) }^{ n-x }

In this case, n = 8 (the total number of occurrences), x = 5 (the occurrences we are trying to find the probability for) and \pi = 0.5 (the probability of occurrence x).

While this formula is given on the AP test, one can think of it logically. In order to get 5\text{ heads} out of 8\text{ tosses}, one needs to get:

\dbinom{8}{5}=\dfrac{8!}{5!\cdot 3!}

Therefore, all 3\text{ elements} need to be part of the solution. Since multiplication is commutative, these three elements can be in any order.

Note: 8! = (8)\cdot(7)\cdot(6)\cdot(5)\cdot(4)\cdot(3)\cdot(2)\cdot(1)
